turn.2: But while the secular authorities endeavored to regulate the relations of the Jews to the country at large in accordance with its economic needs, the clergy, inspired by the attempts of the Roman Catholic Church to establish its universal supremacy, used its influence toward separating the Jews from the body politic, aiming to exclude them, as people dangerous to the Church, from Christian society, and to place them in the position of a despised "sect".
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: In 1266 an ecumenical council was held at Wrocław under the chairmanship of the papal nuncio Guido.
turn.5: What was the result of the council?
turn.6: The council introduced into the ecclesiastical statutes of Poland a number of paragraphs directed against the Jews.
turn.8: The Jews were ordered to dispose as quickly as possible of real estate owned by them in the Christian quarters; they were not to appear on the streets during Church processions; they were allowed to have only a single synagogue in any one town; and they were required to wear a special cap to distinguish them from the Christians.
turn.10: The latter were forbidden, under penalty of excommunication, to invite Jews to feasts or other entertainments, and were forbidden also to buy meat or other provisions from Jews, for fear of being poisoned.
turn.11: What else was the significance of the council?
turn.12: The council furthermore confirmed the regulations under which Jews were not allowed to keep Christian servants, to lease taxes or customs duties, or to hold any public office.
